DOCNAME: CASE OF ELLI POLUHAS DÖDSBO v. SWEDEN
JUDGES: András Baka;Antonella Mularoni;Elisabet Fura;Jean-Paul Costa;Karel Jungwiert;Mindia Ugrekhelidze
TEXT: CARDINAL . In DATE the applicant married an NORP national of NORP origin who had entered GPE that DATE . CARDINAL children were born of the marriage . The family lived in PERSON , where the applicant ’s husband worked as a sales manager until his death on CARDINAL DATE . His ashes were buried in a family grave at a cemetery in PERSON . The grave has room for CARDINAL other urns . The contract on the burial plot is to expire on DATE , but will automatically be renewed for DATE when a new burial takes place there . Moreover , the person in possession of the right to the burial plot when the contract is about to expire is entitled to renew it .
CARDINAL . In DATE the applicant moved to Västerås to be closer to her children . The distance between PERSON and Västerås is QUANTITY .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant requested the cemetery authorities ( NORP - Västervåla Kyrkogårdsförvaltning ) to allow the transfer of her husband ’s urn to her family burial plot in GPE , which had been established in DATE and had room for CARDINAL urns . The applicant ’s parents were buried there and the applicant intended to be buried there after her death . GPE is situated QUANTITY from GPE . The applicant submitted in addition that she had no connection to PERSON any more , that all her children agreed to the removal and that she was sure her husband would not have objected to the transfer .
CARDINAL . By a decision of DATE , her request was refused by the authorities in deference to the notion of “ a peaceful rest ” under LAW ( Begravningslagen , PERSON ) .
CARDINAL . NORP On appeal , ORG in GPE ( GPE i PERSON ) upheld the refusal .
CARDINAL . The applicant appealed to ORG in GPE ( Länsrätten i LOC ) which , by a decision of CARDINAL DATE , found against her . It stated as follows :

“ Pursuant to LAW , section CARDINAL , of LAW , remains or ashes which have been buried in a cemetery may not be removed from a burial plot in order to be buried in another burial plot . However , permission may be granted if there are special reasons therefor and the place to which the remains or ashes are to be removed has been determined .

According to the explanatory notes to LAW . CARDINAL , pp . DATE ) , the decision on a request for the removal of remains or ashes shall be restrictive , having regard to the deceased ’s right to a peaceful rest . Determination [ of such a request ] should be guided by the wishes expressed by the deceased whilst alive . As a general rule , it must be assumed that such a wish , if expressed , was taken into account when the burial took place . The paramount condition for allowing a transfer is obviously that it would not contravene the wishes expressed by the deceased when alive . Moreover , some connection between the deceased and the intended destination would usually be required .

In the present case [ the applicant ’s husband ] worked as a sales manager at the PERSON factory until DATE . He died on CARDINAL DATE , and the urn containing his ashes was placed in grave no . CARDINAL , quarter no . CARDINAL , in Västerfors . [ The applicant ’s husband ] came from GPE and had a ORG tradition . It appears that he did not express any wishes about his burial when he was alive .
ORG makes the following assessment :

Making an overall assessment , ORG finds that [ the applicant ’s husband ] did not have a closer natural connection to GPE than he had to PERSON . No other reasons have been submitted which could justify the disturbance of the peace of the grave after DATE . ”
CARDINAL . The applicant ’s request for leave to appeal was refused by ORG in GPE ( Kammarrätten i GPE ) on DATE , and by ORG ( Regeringsrätten ) on DATE .
CARDINAL . The applicant died on DATE . In accordance with her wishes , she was buried in her family burial plot in GPE .

CARDINAL . Domestic provisions of relevance to the present case are to be found in LAW DATE ( Begravningslagen – “ the LAW ” ) , which came into force on DATE . Previously , they were contained in LAW DATE ( NORP om jordfästning m.m . ) .

It is mainly the parishes of ORG which are responsible for burial grounds ( LAW , section CARDINAL , of the Act ) and for decisions concerning , inter alia , graves and burials . It is also in the first instance for the church authorities to determine requests to move the remains or ashes of a deceased person ( Chapters CARDINAL , DATE and QUANTITY ) . A decision may be appealed to the county administrative board ( LAW , section CARDINAL , of the Act ) . Further appeals lie with the competent administrative court of appeal and , subject to the granting of leave to appeal , with ORG ( LAW , section CARDINAL , of the LAW ) .

When a person dies , his or her wishes concerning cremation and burial should , as far as possible , be followed ( LAW , LAW ) . This was also the rule under LAW DATE , the legislation applicable at the time of the applicant ’s husband ’s death . If there is a dispute between the survivors about where the burial should take place , it is for the GPE administrative board to decide ( LAW , section CARDINAL , of the Act ) .

Once remains or ashes have been buried , moving them from CARDINAL place to another is in principle not allowed . However , permission to move remains or ashes may be granted if special reasons exist and if the place to which they will be moved has been clearly stated ( LAW , section CARDINAL , of the Act ) . However , the grave must not be opened in such a way that the remains or ashes are damaged ( LAW , LAW , of the LAW ) .

The provisions of LAW , section CARDINAL , of the Act are based on respect for the sanctity of the grave . This is also why the provisions regarding the removal of remains and ashes are restrictive ; a deceased ’s grave must be left in peace and may only be disturbed under special circumstances . According to the explanatory notes to LAW PERSON , p. CARDINAL ) , the removal of remains or ashes may be permitted if a mistake occurred at the time of burial , if the remains of a husband , wife , parent or young child are to be brought together or , in some cases , if a refugee or immigrant wishes to take the remains of a deceased relative back to his or her country of origin . The deceased ’s own wishes should serve as guidance for the transfer decision . When such wishes are not known , regard should be had to the deceased ’s attachment to the place where he or she is buried . As a rule , removal should not be permitted if the deceased is buried in a place where he or she was active for a large part of his or her life . If , however , the cemetery is situated in a place where the deceased lived only temporarily , removal may be permitted .

In addition , the deceased should have had some connection with the place to which the remains are to be removed . According to the explanatory notes ( ibid . , pp . DATE ) , examples of such a connection could be that the deceased grew up in that place , had relatives or a family grave there , or perhaps had a holiday home there . As regards husbands and wives , it may be permitted to move CARDINAL of the deceased ’s remains to bring them together in a common grave , especially if the one who died last can not , for some reason , be buried in the same place as the first . Particular regard may be had to the wishes of the last survivor concerning the common burial place .

CARDINAL . In DATE ORG ruled on several cases concerning the interpretation of LAW , section CARDINAL , of the LAW ( PERSON DATE ref . CARDINAL I - IV ) . These judgments reveal a restrictive interpretation . For instance , the fact that the surviving relatives have moved , that there is a long distance between the burial place and their new home , or that public transport to a burial place may be lacking , are not considered to be sufficient grounds for a transfer . In CARDINAL cases ORG , referring to the explanatory notes to the LAW and the reasons stated in the requests , found that those reasons were not sufficient to permit removal of the deceased ’s remains or ashes . These cases concerned , respectively , a fiancée who wanted to move her fiancé ’s remains , a husband who wanted to move his wife ’s remains , and a daughter who wanted to move her father ’s remains . In another case , however , which concerned a mother ’s request to move her child ’s remains to her husband ’s burial place , ORG found that there were sufficient reasons to allow the transfer .

In the case concerning a daughter ’s request to move her father ’s remains , the former wanted to bury the latter in the same cemetery as the one in which her recently deceased mother had chosen to be buried . ORG noted that the complainant ’s father had lived and worked in GPE , and was buried there in his grandfather ’s family grave . Having regard to the father ’s connection to GPE , ORG found no reason to presume that his burial there had been a mistake , and it held that there were no other sufficient reasons , after DATE , to permit the removal of the remains .
